children.subject: Why these specific slides if I may ask?
They are more detailed because they were tailored for a smaller class size. sorry I meant spring 2018. You can look around and you will soon understand. gl!
Lol spring 18 61c was the worst 61c. Don’t look at those. Look at Garcia’s.
Can you please confirm that you really mean summer 2018. Lol. Just to be sure.
for 61c go study the slides from summer 2017 site! You won’t regret it!

That's going to be a tough schedule.

For CS 170, I think the most useful thing for winter break study would be to read the textbook and (if you are up to it) do some of the problems at the end of each chapter.  The 170 textbook is concise and (after a few reads) accessible, and the class follows the material quite closely. Also, I found that reading the textbook beforehand was crucial to being able to understand the lecture and to be able to attempt the homework competently.  If you read it over winter break and attempt some of the problems, during the school year, there'll be less initial confusion that comes with learning a new topic.

history.content:
This shouldn't be that bad of a schedule. I think 61C is roughly as hard as 61B, and personally I thought 170 was easier than 70 (though the consensus seems to be they are about the same). 170 psets take about 10 hours a week, which hardly sucks amortized over 7 days.

I think studying ahead is overkill. Just chill out for now and enjoy your break.

children.subject: I personally did not like him. Talks about random stuff in class, doesn't explain much during lecture but just reads off the slides, essentially making it a self-study class. And then guess what, you study your heart out and he makes exams that aim to achieve a "mean" distribution simply by obscurity: super unfair. But he does have a nice curve in the end so that helps..
That is disconcerting. How is it a nice curve when there are letter grades for each point value?
To the anon above-above, what do you mean by 'obscurity'?

Putting stuff on exams "barely" covered or even not covered in lecture/material. His argument is that you should "learn" from the tests as well. I'm ok with that but not at the expense of my grades lol
Does anyone know how Nick Weaver was as a professor? I remember some people said stuff about him but I can't remember if they were meme or not

61C- harder than 61B conceptually, slightly easier projects

170- depending on what you liked/found easy, you might have different opinions. If you liked the theory part of 61B and the mathematical nature of 70(discrete specifically), this is the course for you. Otherwise, it'll be harder.
If I did 61B and 70 this semester, how does 61C and 170 compare?

history.content:
Hey y’all,

So, as the post indicates, I enrolled in both CS170 and CS61C together for the upcoming Spring 2019 semester. I’ve heard from people on this forum how difficult this schedule is going to be, especially for someone who barely passed CS70, and also didn’t perform partícularly well in CS61B. However, am willing to put in the work required for both classes (it just occurred to me that I might actually want to go to grad school, so I have no choice but to perform higher than average in all my classes henceforth). 
My question is, how do I get ahead in both of these classes? 
For 170, do I just watch the lecture videos, and do the homeworks as if am actually taking the class? Also, for CS61C, should I spend my time learning C and RISC-V or just follow along the lectures & homeworks as if am taking the class? 

How far should I go into preparing for these classes? While some might recommend that I spend this break relaxing so as to get my mind off school for a while, I still feel like going into next semester knowing what to expect has the most return on my academics in the long run. Thoughts?
history.subject: PREPARING FOR CS170 & CS61C
